reviewText: Having never heard of or seen any previous versions, I did not know what to expect but was intrigued by the thought of stand up comedy that did not use profanity and crudeness to get a cheap laugh.  While this definitely fit the bill for most of those things, it came up really short on comedy.  I now know why the title is what it is - you are being commanded to laugh even if it is not funny.  I found it to be rather bland and boring, and not even worthy of a cheap rental.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: This was the first volume of "Thou Shalt Laugh" that I have seen, but I was impressed enough by positive reviews of the previous volumes to give it a shot.  I enjoy stand-up comedy of all kinds, and I was intrigued by the promise of clean "Christian comedy" offered by this series.  This 90-minute program was shot live at a Texas church, so the production values are decent but not spectacular.As promised, the comedy was fit for the entire family.  My wife was anticipating Christian-themed acts, but only Michael, Jr. delivered Bible-inspired humor.  The acts were pleasantly varied, with a musician and ventriloquist/magician.  Unfortunately, the acts were largely hit or miss.  Joe Wong and Isaac Witty were simply not funny in my opinion, and the others were good but none left me rolling in the aisle.  John Tesh, meanwhile, was an affable host and an awkward, unfunny comedian as he demonstrated throughout.  Although teasing the audience with the possibility that he might perform a musical number, Tesh was largely absent during the program and, in the end, served little purpose other than name recognition for the box.If you are a fan of the series, you will probably get this volume regardless.  If you are new to the series, like me, you might want to start with an earlier volume, if all of those positive reviews are to be believed.
summary: Family friendly, but only moderately funny
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Realizing that different people have different opinions on what is funny and what is not, I am rating this DVD as 4 stars for my own sense of humor, which tends to be somewhat wide-ranged from subtle to almost slap-stick.Three of the six comedians on this DVD really impressed me, especially Rex Havens, the lead-off one.  His bit about car names, men and women, and shoes was hilarious.  Joe Wong, the second presenter, had a few good lines, but his pace was way too slow - something he shared with many of the other comedians.  Dana Daniels, the magician/comedian, was a bit slow-paced, but his interaction with the people he volunteered from the audience was outstanding.  He was very quick with funny comebacks and his overall act was quite entertaining.  Michael Jr. was excellent in spots, but was not consistently funny (to me).  Isaac Witty did not keep my attention, so I'm not sure if that was my fault or his.  The last comedian on the DVD was Taylor Mason, a very talented ventriloquist/pianist with a high energy level who was the perfect choice for closing the show.Although there were several lines about Christians from a few of the comedians, the humor was not overtly Christian throughout.  My favorite one, Rex Havens, joked about everyday experiences that men and women have and elevated simple observations to hilarious insights.John Tesh did an outstanding job as MC.  His attempts at humor were well accepted by the audience and even made me smile.I enjoyed watching the DVD and plan to have it handy so I can view it the next time I need a good laugh.  It will be something I can safely show to friends and family when they visit.
summary: Adult humor, rated G for the family
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Six comedians on stage - four very funny...Material was clever, interesting and clean.  Particularly enjoed the segment on cars, weddings, being 'over saved.'With no laugh tracks one can be true to themselves as they enjoy the routines.Expect to share with family and Christian friends...a job well done.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: After watching this DVD I realized how thankful I need to be to have co-workers and friends who are a lot funnier than some of the guys in this show. And they don't have to make dirty jokes either. Just like the title implies ("Thou Shalt..."), the laughter in this presentation is forced in many instances. True, there are some good jokes, like the one with the checkbook split in which the guy takes the deposit slips and the wife the checks, but I already heard many of them. In retrospective, I think it would have been more efficient on my part to have some of the jokes printed out, rather than to have to wait for the whole presentation to develop.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Geared towards fundamentalist Christians this clean comedy has some really funny moments dominated by two of the comedians (Michael Jr and Taylor Mason), but is mostly mediocre. Some of the comedians are downright odd and unfunny. The host, John Tesh, is the most well known of all of the people on the show appears the most out of place on the show as well. I love stand up, consider myself a devoted Christian, and I laughed out loud once the entire run of the show.Many of the jokes are forced or old material and the audience seems to laugh out of politeness, and other times simply don't laugh at all. When the jokes do become explicitly Christian they do alienate anyone who is not a fundamentalist or generic evangelical. For instance, one comedian jokes about James the "brother of Jesus" as if he were Jesus' blood brother, son of Mary. Most of Christendom would recognize that interpretation as an amateur violation of the biblical text. Unfortunately situations like that make the jokes unfunny for many viewers.I would rent this movie before purchasing it unless you are already an established fan of the series.
summary: Some funny comedy marred by amateur theology
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: This is the best of the "thou Shalt Laugh" series.All of the other videos I rented first to see if worth buying.NOPE, they were not in our opinion as a familyThey were hit or miss on the funny..usually 2 to 1 on misses.This however is consistent in the humourClean cut , Christian funSome potential Bill Cosbys in the group..seeing the absurd in everdyay thingsThis is one you can buy and will watch more than once..maybe invite others over for a comedyevening w/ popcorn !This is a very hard genre to be funny inMost comedians have to sink to swearing, sex jokes or toilet type humourIt takes a lot of talent to stay clean and funnyIf you want clean cut family fun....this is it !!!
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Good family safe comedy! "Thou Shalt Laugh 4" is, as you might expect, the fourth installment in this Christian based stand up comedy series. We have the first three of these and enjoyed the first two very much but was disappointed with some inappropriate content in the 3rd one, so we were a little leery about this DVD. I'm happy to report that this release was perfectly safe for the whole family, with only some subtle minor jokes about bra sizes and circumcision but nothing explicit.The show is hosted by the talented radio personality John Tesh and includes comedians Dana Daniels, Taylor Mason, Joe Wong, Michael Jr., Isaac Witty, and Rex Havens. While some of the acts are hit and miss, for the most part they are all at least humorous and often are laugh out loud funny.It is refreshing to have access to family safe stand up that we can put on and not have to worry about foul language or "shock" content. The religious content is in good taste and not overly proselytizing (the "Creepy Christians" bit was very funny).Recommended!CFH
summary: Family Safe Stand Up Comedy - Recommended!
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Thou Shall Laugh 4 - Fun FAMILY Comedy.While this DVD is enjoyable, it is not side splitting uproariously funny. It is very much  along the lines of old Ed Sullivan variety TV show. I had three generations of people watching it at one time and while the adults enjoyed it quite a bid, the teenage kids for the most part thought that it was pretty lame.Once again it was fun, but it seemed like even the producers were not quite sure of that. There are more than the usual number of cuts to the audience laughing. Braces joke = shot of a girl with braces, fat joke or ethnic joke = likewise. Yes there are tasteful ethnic jokes.The entire show takes place inside a church as we find out from one of the comedians. John Tesh does a very professional MC act, and even throws in a few jokes based on him growing up. Telling of these stories he describes as therapy, not as comedy.Here are my takes on the comedians:Rex Havens: ****. Very much in the style of George Carlin. In other words, he has fun with language and words, car names, women's shoes, etc. Very good with facial gestures.Joe Wong: **** Somewhat hard to understand with a thick Chinese accent, but he makes that a central point of his routine. Fitting in in Texas, becoming a citizen, becoming a father. Pretty good story teller.Dana Daniel's: ***** A BAD magician/animal trainer (he's a BIRD!). This as it turns out becomes his strength. Magic so bad that its really funny. After a slow start, he was the only one that made me laugh out loud. He does throw in some passing gas jokes though. Aaah.... the classics of comedy.Michael Jr: ***** If your church or civic group ever had an engaging motivational speaker, he was probably a lot like Michael Jr. He starts out describing his uncertainty with being Christian and evolves it into funny stories. What is  that fine line between being a non believer or too much of a believer? Michael explores it.Isaac Witty: ** I watched the entire act hoping it was going to become funny. For me it never did. Not many others in my group thought it was funny either.Taylor Mason: ****  A pretty good ventriloquist, especially with the stuffed pig. But no so much with the puppets, but still good.  At one point he has two large puppets have a pretty funny discussion with each other, but has some difficulty controlling both well. His simplest routines evoked the most laughs out of the audience. He is also a talented piano player, and he ends his act by drawing John Tesh into a piano duet with him. John's contribution turns out to very limited.So overall, while not quite Cosby and Reagan caliber, still good for quite a few laughs.Moreover a fine show that you would not be embarrassed to watch with the wife, kids, AND grandparents.
summary: Thou Shall Laugh 4 - Fun FAMILY Comedy
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Our family watched this DVD the other night and found it entertaining and family friendly. There is good fun without offensive or suggestive language. The format is familiar with John Tesh as MC and six Christian stand-up comedians.An interesting feature of the DVD is the considerable differences between the styles of the six comedians; some of them are truly original, like nothing we had ever seen before.The DVD provides an evening of lighthearted fun that the entire family can enjoy; I found myself doing a lot of laughing! It's the kind of thing you can enjoy with your friends without having to apologize for anything.The performance is live before a huge audience at the Bay Area Fellowship Church in Corpus Christi, Texas. Views of the audience give the impression that this is a really large church. The live audience response gives one a feeling of participating in a really big event.I have not seen the first three performances, but as John Tesh points out at the beginning, that is not a requirement to enjoy this one, and we did.There is an excellent special feature by Michael Jr: "Comedy... On The Road Less Traveled," that you want to be sure and watch. It gives some new insights into the role Christian comedians can play in life. I think you'll be blessed
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: When I decided to get this DVD I was a bit apprehensive since I hadn't seen any of the others in the series and it is billed as Christian comedy.The fact of the matter is it is easy to suck doing comedy and doing clean comedy seems to be very difficult - witness the tiny sliver of standup that you'd be comfortable watching with your grandmother. Right? Even fairly clean comedians have some very tasteless parts of their acts. It is frustrating if you'd like to share it/them with someone close with a similar sense of humor but the bad part(s) always drown out the very funny stuff before or after.So, thinking of Sinbad's special from a few years ago -Sinbad: Son of A Preacher Man- I went ahead and got this one.Really, very enjoyable! Not everyone was knockdown funny but all were good for some laughs and a few were funny all the way through. Joe Wong in particular was great and his type, or sense maybe, of comedy was dead on for me.Good clean humor. Even, for this venue, some risqué stuff from one guy which kind of stuck out to me because it made me wonder how far it could go considering the Christian label. It didn't go far. Perhaps I expected the worst :pI was surprised to see John Tesh hosting but I never have kept up with him since he left ET so long ago. I knew he has had a successful career playing the piano. He did a great job of course since he has entertained huge audiences for many years he was very comfortable on the stage. He wasn't terrifically funny but he did give you an urge to see the next person in the line up. haha.Darin
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I could only stand to watch about 20 minutes of this dvd.I never even smirked... was just not funny - the only thing I could recommend this for is if your having trouble sleeping pop this in an it will help tire you out but that is about it.Grade: F all over.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Though I'd heard of this series of comedy DVD's before, I had not yet had the opportunity to see one, but as a sophisticated connoisseur of comedy (i.e. a guy who likes stuff that makes him laugh), I leapt at the chance to try one.I haven't laughed this hard in a very long time!I'm old enough to remember when comedians had to clean up their material before going on TV, and IMHO most of them benefitted from the experience...because it made them work (think) a little harder.Not that I believe blue humor can never be hilarious, but IMHO too many comedians use it simply as a brainless shortcut to laughs while only a rare few are masters of it.  Besides, you can't watch it with the whole family.So A plus for the concept, but how's the execution?  Well, though it falls short of perfection,...it doesn't fall too short IMHO!John Tesh does a good job of emceeing, poking fun at himself and keeping his bits funny and SHORT, which is the key IMHO.  In addition the six comedians, two returnees and four rookies, provide a good mix of comedy styles.Up first is Rex Havens who has a hilarious bit poking fun at the peculiarity of car names if you stop to think about it, segueing into another good bit about the double standards applied to men and women in marriage.Second is Chinese immigrant to Texas Joe Wong who arguably provides the most uncommon viewpoint.  We've had lots of immigrant comedians commenting on the funny things about America from the newcomer's POV, but this is the first Chinese one I've seen.  He also provides the one clunker of a joke.  If he rewrote the punch line to "The reason our convenience store no longer gets robbed?" I'm sure he'd get a much bigger laugh.Third is Dana Daniels with a hilarious parody of an incompetent magician complete with "trained" bird and deliberately disastrous audience participation.Fourth is returnee Michael Jr., arguably both the most professional and the most overtly Christian, with a hilarious bit about "creepy Christians" or as he puts it, "the Oversaved."Fifth is Isaac Witty with several bits about his social awkwardness.  If the show had to be cut down to five, his is the act that I'd cut, not because it wasn't funny (it was), but because it was the least funny IMHO.Last is returnee Taylor Mason who does several hilarious ventriloquist bits, displaying astonishing skill at it.  He also works John Tesh into a funny piano bit at the end.Unfortunately, I must now confess to being well and truly hooked!  I will certainly select Thou Shalt Laugh 5, 6, 7, etc., if I ever get the chance (HINT!  HINT!), but I'm probably going to have to shell out actual cash forThou Shalt Laugh,Thou Shalt Laugh 2 - The Deuce, andThou Shalt Laugh 3.(sigh) Another incentive to find work and to find it quickly!
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Yes, the title of this CD is THOU SHALT LAUGH.  Well, I don't really need to be commanded to laugh, urged to laugh or even gently reminded to so because I truly love to laugh.  Unfortunately, the line of comedians presented here didn't elicit many laugh-out-loud times from me but did bring forth smiles.Emmy Award winner, radio talk show host, and musician John Tesh is, of course, and amicable host.  He conveys sincere warmth and enthusiasm.Now, rather than risk spoilers I'm not going to quote any of the comedians - suffice it to say that their humor is gentle and well meaning.  As I indicated these are not words to bring forth chortles or guffaws but rather smiles of appreciation or understanding.My biggest smiles were for Taylor Mason who mixes ventriloquism and piano with his stand-up routine, and Michael Jr.'s take on "creepy Christians."- Gail Cooke
summary: SMILE PROVOKING BUT NOT LAUGH OUTLOUD FUNNY
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I've never seen the first three Thou Shalt Laugh DVDs, but I thought I'd give the fourth installment a try. Some of the jokes are a bit dated, especially the ones from Rex Havens about all the different cars. At first I thought the DVD was made in 2009 but was filmed much earlier, until Rex made a few cracks about newer cars (Dodge Journey, Ford Focus) and even included a quip about President Obama. Taylor Mason also included a humorous sketch about a pig puppet with a face mask (obvious reference to the Mexican Swine Flu or H1N1) and added a joke about Vice President Joe Biden.I'd have to say Isaac Witty and Dana Daniels weren't the most funny, but they had their moments. Rex Havens had some knee slapping jokes, as did Michael Jr. Joe Wong had some great jokes but I didn't particularly enjoy his delivery. It seemed too wooden and slow. I can understand the desire to let the audience absorb the joke, but it was always 2-3 seconds more than what I felt was a comfortable pace. It looked like Joe didn't have as many jokes and wanted to pass the time more easily.You can expect to find clean humor in this DVD, with the most "extreme" of jokes referencing dating, women, relationships, and a tiny bit of political humor. John Tesh's main job was to simply introduce the comedians, but he managed to inject a few jokes here and there.
summary: Good clean comedy, a bit dry at times
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Well When I ordered  this DVD was not sure what to expect, as I had not watched any of the previous DVD's. I have to say how pleasently surprised I was with it. All very funny sets, just the right length. This DVD series proves you don't have to swear or be crude to be funny. Very entertaining Family fair, without any of the worries that you can't let your kids watch this with you. I laughed throughout most of the DVD. I was a bit worried that I would not enjoy it, do to its Christian roots, but quickly was relieved to see there was not much religion pumped into it. If you have any intrest in comedy without the swearing and sexual banter, then this fills the bill very nicely.
summary: Comedy you can watch with your kids
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: There is an obvious emphasis on being unoffensive, even "Christian" (culturally Christian, like the I have a Christian dog, Christian cat, and Christian lawn, nothing to do with doctrine kind of Christian) in these routines. I have to admit, I am immediately skeptical of any of these Christian-trying-to-emulate-something-the-world-does kinds of products. Nevertheless, my wife and I definitely laughed and thoroughly enjoyed most of this dvd.The magician was poor, but the rest of the routines were funny, some (Joe Wong in particular) were even incredibly memorable. I could definitely see us watching this again in the future. That in and of itself was a pleasant surprise.
summary: We Laughed. I was pleasantly surprised
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewerName: Jason P. Pumphrey "the movie & music man"
reviewText: Here's something you don't get often, clean cut comedy! Hosted by the one and only John Tesh. This has 6 great Christian comedians: Rex Havens, Joe Wang, Dana Daniels, Michael Jr, Issac Witty, and Taylor Mason. The only gripe I have w/ this DVD is that it was filmed in widescreen but the presentation is presented in 4:3 and is "windowboxed" on 16:9 TV's, hence the 4 star rating I gave for this. It should have be mastered in "anamorphic widescreen".
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Everyone has heard that laughter is the best medicine.  Proverbs 17:22 (Amplified) says, "A happy heart is good medicine and a cheerful mind works healing, but a broken spirit dries up the bones."  I love to laugh.  When I'm feeling sad, I watch the "Thou Shalt Laugh" comedy series.  I was excited to be able to preview a copy of the latest installment.  My parents were visiting from Tennessee and they watched it along with me.It is difficult to find comedy presentations that my parents and I can watch together.  Comedians on the Comedy Channel are often offensive, using vulgar and sexually explicit language.  With the "Thou Shalt Laugh" series, I feel comfortable watching it with my parents and other relatives and friends.  I don't have to worry about foul language and sexually explicit material."Thou Shalt Laugh 4" is on a par with the other installments in the series.  This one is hosted by John Tesh, former host of "Entertainment Tonight."  He introduces six comedians in the following order: Rex Havens, Joe Wong, Dana Daniels, Michael Jr., Isaac Witty and Taylor Mason.My favorite comedian is Rex Havens.  My family and I laughed non-stop through his entire routine, which consisted of two segments.  In the first, he pokes fun of automobile names.  He once owned a Plymouth Reliant; it made him more reliant on public transportation.  In the second segment, Rex describes how the wedding day is totally for the bride.  She doesn't even want the groom there.Joe Wong was hilarious with his immigrant jokes, especially the ones pertaining to his struggles to pass the citizenship test.  For example, one question on the test asked what was Roe versus Wade.  Joe answered that it was two ways for getting into this country.Dana Daniels had an adorable parrot whose "psychic powers" were uproarious.  Taylor Mason is famous for his ventriloquist dummies.  Isaac Witty is great as a dimwit who is rather slow.  Michael Jr. rolled me over when he recalled how a heckler at one of his performances had asked him why all black men looked alike.  He simply told the heckler that he needed to make the eye holes in his white sheet larger so he could see them more clearly.My only complaint with the DVD was the absence of subtitles for those of us who are hearing impaired.  However, the audio is loud and clear and the video looked great on my high definition television.  Also, the menu enables the viewer to jump from one of their favorite comedians to another."Thou Shalt Laugh 4" is highly recommended for Christians and their families who crave clean, wholesome comedy entertainment.  I'm proud to have added it to my collection and can hardly wait for the next installment in this award winning series.  I'm glad to be able to watch it with my parents without feeling embarrassed and ashamed!  Most importantly, I'm glad I can watch it with God without feeling embarrassed and ashamed!Joseph B. Hoyos
summary: I Can Watch It With My Parents Without Feeling Embarrassed Or Ashamed!
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Funny and entertaining and in a good clean way.  Kids can enjoy it as well.  Not that they will get everything but teenagers can.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I have to admit that I was not familiar with the Thou Shalt Laugh series, but like anyone I enjoy a good comedy show.  Traditionally, I have been a fan of the likes of Sam Kinison, Chris Rock, and Rodney Dangerfield, but I am fully aware that these acts are not for everyone and are certainly not appropriate for younger children.  I have to admit that I was a bit skeptical of the family comedy concept, but I popped in the DVD with an open mind.I was not completely disappointed in the video, but none of the comedians really gave me more than a few chuckles.  In my opinion, it seemed that the show was led off by their best comedians.I quite enjoyed Rex Havens' rant on marriage and his clever synopsis of cars.  Joe Wong's observational humor as seen through the eyes of a person "new" to America was priceless.  After these two acts, I thought the quality of the show went downhill.  As a matter of fact, I thought Dana Daniels and his parrot was the low point of the show.  With nowhere to go but up, Michael Jr. had a clever part of his act on the topic of religious friends.  Issac Witty was a close second when it came to the honor of being the low point of the video.  Even if I ignored his idiotic demeanor and terrible timing on his delivery, the part of his act about a church greeter with missing fingers really turned me off to him (not that the topic was taboo with me, it just was not funny).  The show wraps up with Taylor Mason, a seemingly talented ventriloquist, but I was not impressed with his act.John Tesh served as MC for the show.  Maybe my expectations were too high, but I expect a MC at a comedy show to be entertaining, tell a few jokes, or maybe tell a story or two.  He tried to do all of these, and I felt he did a very lackluster job of it.Comedians are like pizzas, they are a very personal thing and everyone has different tastes.  What one person thinks is great another person thinks is terrible.  This DVD is just like every comedy club show I have been to, some comedians are very good, a few are OK, and some are terrible.  Overall, while I would not call this DVD a waste of time, I was not overly impressed either.  If you are looking for something you wanted to sit down and watch with your 10+ year old kids, this might be worth checking out.  This is one of those videos that I would feel like I got ripped off if I paid full-price.  I'd recommended renting or borrowing the video if at all possible.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I love comedy, well... I loved comedy, but something went terribly wrong and we started getting a lot of comedians who couldn't be smart and funny in a clean way that was family friendly. Larry the cable guy and Ron White for example are 2 of the more well known comedians who are funny, but not suitable for the younger audience to watch.That's where this DVD comes in. While I didn't find all the comedians funny, and there were a few I thought were just down right annoying there was enough good humor to keep me entertained. I loved the magic of Dana Daniels with his bird sidekick. I've seen similar acts before but it's still enough to make you laugh out loud.Then there was Rex Havens who took the names of cars and really had a great act that had me rolling.Those were the 2 main comedians I enjoyed in this DVD, the others were entertaining and had some good jokes but Dana and Rex were what sealed it for me. The one thing I didn't like was at some parts I felt like I was being preached to by the comedians and I wasn't looking for that, I was instead looking for clean humor that was funny, that was it. That's why this lost one star. I understand the series is founded based on Christian beliefs by and for Christians and I have no issue with that, in fact I applaud that concept, but I think they over sell that to much and thus others might be turned away and it also loses some of the entertainment value because of that. Rex and Dana on the other hand don't even talk about the bible, they just have fun with magic and everyday items.Is it worth getting? It depends on the price. As of me writing this amazon has it on sale for $19.98, a price I personally would NEVER pay for this type of DVD. I could see paying as much as $15.00 but I think I would hold out until I could find it  for $10 or less. Honestly to me that's the value I would put on it. So if you like all these comedians it may be worth the full $20 price tag to you, if your like me and only a few acts really entertain you then you may want to buy it used or wait until amazon lowers the price of the new.
summary: Very funny, great clean family humor everyone can enjoy.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Thou Shalt Laugh 4 contains good clean humor for the whole family to enjoy.  The DVD was completely family-friendly. Many comedians appearing on prime time TV are just plain crass anymore, and not suitable for family viewing.  No crassness is contained in Thou Shalt Laugh 4.The comedians on the disc had a broad range of humor styles, which further contributed to the entertainment value of the DVD.  I especially liked the fact that the DVD was "for Christians, by Christians".  Thou Shalt Laugh 4 made me laugh out loud quite a few times with jokes that were sometimes silly, sometimes serious and sometimes just plain fun.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Yes, you can enjoy your food while watching this DVD because nothing is funny enough to induce you to choke on your food with laughter.Oh, there are some funny moments, but good humor should have more than one laugh every fifteen minutes.Rex Havens has a good routine about car names, but it mostly gets worse from there.  Joe Wong seems like a novice with no experience in performing as he delivers a completely humor free routine.  Dana Daniels is downright terrible.  Michael Jr is ok and delivers one good line at the end of his routine. Isaac Witty... zzz zzz zzz oh, sorry, I fell asleep.  The final comedian, Taylor Mason, is a talented ventriloquist and pianist.  Overall this DVD is funny and it should put a smile on your face.There is no reason clean humor can't be hilarious.  Bill Cosby delivered a ton of clean humor in the 1960s which was creative and "roll on the floor" "laugh out loud" funny. This DVD in contrast barely rates a chuckle.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: It is refreshing to watch a comedy routine where the comedian doesn't have to rely on dropping the f-bomb every fifteen seconds or making drug references in order to garner laughs. That type of comedy is funny (after three beers) and has its place (college campuses), but it gets old pretty quick."Thou 4" is a compilation of various styles of comedians with different levels of hilarity ranging from amusing to laugh-out-loud funny. It's not all good, but it's never bad (in any connotation). Of course, it's comedy, so some of the comedians resort to using f-bombs of another kind, that being bodily functions.All-in-all, this is a good, family friendly program. You won't laugh so hard your stomach hurts, but it's worth a purchase.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Thou Shalt Laugh 4 doesn't fail: it's hilarious!  It's full of comedy, edgy enough to please secular audiences, but deeply grounded in clean, wholesome family themes.  TSL 4 features several Christian comics including Rex Havens, Michael Jr., and perennial favorite Taylor Mason.  The jokes are funny, the comedy is clean, and it sure is a wonderful alternative to other videos on the market.  Highly recommended.
summary: Great Clean, Wholesome Fun for the Family
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Who knew John Tesh could be so funny?  This DVD has the same electricity that has made this franchise such a hit.  Six zinger comedians who all work clean perform together, each trying to outdo each other, so no matter who gets the best laugh, we all win.  If you've enjoyed the last three Thou Shalt Laugh videos, you'll continue enjoying this one.There's some new talent on board.  The opening act, Rex Havens, does rapid-fire banter and hilarious tongue twisters, and he's followed by Joe Wong, who does what many performers claim is impossible: he's funny in a second language.  These guys had me rolling on the floor.  I expect to see them become stars in the near future.And if you've liked Michael Jr. in the previous outings, let me tell you, this is the funniest I've ever seen him.  He still has his natural deadpan, but he seems to have more energy than he's had in the past.  His bit about Creepy Christians hits the audience right where we live, since we've all met these people.  He doesn't miss a trick.Not that everything is perfect.  The last couple of comedians didn't seem to bring their A game.  I don't mean that they aren't funny--I laughed at every single performer--but both of them sort of peter out.  And Taylor Mason, who is like Jeff Dunham for the clean comedy crowd, does so well, but ends on a predictable joke.But on the whole, this is a sharp, funny, worthy addition to the Thou Shalt Laugh tradition.  I laughed until I cried, and then I showed it to friends, and they laughed.  For families, church groups, or anyone who wants to laugh without being barraged with dirty words, this video is sure to be a hit.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: ...and I didn't particularly care for that, either.Maybe I'm alone here, but I've never really equated Christianity with being corny and appealing to the lowest common denominator. Take Bill Cosby, for instance. He's Christian, andBill Cosby, Himselfis probably one of the most hilarious stand up shows I've ever seen, and it gets funnier and more relevant as I get older. I'd gladly watch it with the most devout Christians I know, content in the knowledge that everybody would find parts entertaining, and that only the most sheltered individual alive would seriously take offense.Thou Shalt Laugh 4, however, is not very funny. It's "funny" in the "groaning to be polite" sense of the word, and really did remind me of counselors at a Bible camp I went to in fifth grade. Some of the comedians try their hands at observational humor, which lacks the "humor" component and is mundane at best. Others get a bit more ham-fisted with the Biblical references to the point that it all becomes a bit contrived.I suppose if you've got something to prove to your local priest, minister, reverend, etc., or if you absolutely despise cerebral entertainment, this might be up your alley. But if you're just looking for something funny that you can enjoy with the kids in the room, you're better off looking elsewhere.
summary: This takes me back to Bible camp...
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: The "Thou Shalt Laugh" series has been around for awhile now and this fourth incarnation offers up plenty of clean comedy for the whole family to watch.  But is it really all that funny?  For the most part, yes, the comedy is funny. It isn't always laugh out loud funny and on many occasions it's rather tepid, but as a whole this DVD is pretty good.John Tesh hosts this installment of the comedy series and does a pretty decent job.  He plays the role of emcee quite well and even manages to get in a few laughs of his own.The comedians range from the seemingly new (Joe Wong) to the very experienced (Michael Jr.) and all make the crowd laugh in their own way.  Wong utilizes his "fish out of water" style to generate a number of decent laughs.  I'm particular fond of his explanation of the U.S. citizenship test.  Isaac Witty's performance is sub par, and I let out only a few mild chuckles at his performance.  Rex Havens uses a "play on words" technique that is funny, but drags on a bit too long.  Taylor Mason gives a very erratic performance that ranges from hilarious to completely dull at times.  Dana Daniels does some pretty good "magic" and gave the second best performance in my book.The kings of this DVD, however, were Michael Jr. and a brief segment of jokes told by audience members.  Michael Jr. was funny, period.  His delivery style is very subtle and low-key, but drew big laughs from the crowd.There are funnier clean comedians out there, but "Thou Shalt Laugh" has collected a decent bunch of performers on this disc.  It's safe for the entire family to watch and I believe that just about anyone will enjoy it.  Mildly recommended, with a four star performance from Michael Jr. and three stars to everyone else.
summary: It's Clean Comedy, But Is It Funny?
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Even though this is a "Christian" comedian DVD, the only thing really omitted is foul language. Also, I don't think you have to have any Biblical knowledge to find these comedian's funny. There are very few jokes that require any Biblical background at all. As a matter of fact, only the last comedian told more than one joke that required some Biblical knowledged to understand. However, event though I "got" the jokes, they weren't that funny. I think the funniest comedian on the DVD was Joe Wong ([...]). I never saw him perform before and his humor was totally original to me. I was laughing until I cried. That is pretty rare for me, though I do find that Comedy Central Tosh.0 hilarious too. I didn't think John Tesh was very funny, but he made a good MC and that was his role in this show.This is the kind of show that you can watch in front of children and not worry about exposing them to foul language, or any sexual or violent type talk. One comedian told a couple of jokes that I would consider mean, making fun of someone who lost some fingers. He was the only one to tell such jokes and there weren't a lot of them.On the whole, I haven't seen an overall funnier stand-up comedy set of routines, and I have seen a lot of others. I also regularly watch Comedy Central on Friday night. After seeing "Thou Shalt Laugh 4," I will certainly be checking out the earlier three.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I often wonder how other people think. I know a guy who complained that Soupy Sales was too obscene for him to stand. (Soupy Sales. On TV. In the 1960s. Seriously.) I guess everyone has their line in the sand. I know where mine is, and I guess it would seem weird to someone else.Every time I watch "Christian comedians" I feel like they're more about not crossing their own line than about being funny. That's not to say they can't get off some good lines, but I feel there's a certain uneasiness that gets in the way of the hilarity.The comedians on this disc are a mixed bag of good and not so good. If your first concern is not offending God or your mother, then you will probably find this disc more acceptable than I.But it probably wouldn't hurt John Tesh to take some emceeing lessons from Tom Bergeron.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I have watched this twice now and it is so funny. I love good clean humor and this is it. No foul language or suggestive talk. The whole family can watch this.What makes it so enjoyable are the facial expressions or in one comedians case the lack thereof. I don't want to pick favorites and tell even though I have some but one routine is just so funny I know I'll go back to it again and again it has to do with the names of cars. I just found it hysterical.Besides the MC John Tesh who also contributes humor there are 6 professional comedians. Joe Wong, Issac Witty, Michael Jr. , Dana Daniels, Taylor Mason and Rex Havens (the car name routine).In today"s troubled times and uncertainty we do need to take time and laugh. This is a great way to do it and still feel good about yourself. I highly recommend this to anyone needing a good laugh. I watched it twice in 2 days that should tell you something. :) LOL LOL LOL
summary: Laughter is the Best MEDICINE~Take a dose.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I can't say much about stand-up comedy that can't make me laugh.  Maybe all those years of laughing my a$$ off over George Carlin and Richard Pryor has jaded me, but I couldn't bring myself to laugh even once during the entire DVD and that's pretty sad indeed.
summary: More of a yawn than a yuk fest
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: This provides a mix of comedians.  Some were humorous.  Some were more lame than funny or humorous.  The comedians are all suitable for the entire family, so you can feel confident in watching it with your kids.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I didn't find these comedians very funny.  So I viewed the DVD again with my mom, and she hardly laughed either.  We both agree that Dana Daniels was by far the funniest show on the DVD, and that the rest of the comedians were just not that good.  One guy had such nervous body language that we found him painful to watch and skipped most of his routine.  I'm not sure why this is called Christian comedy... it doesn't have foul language but it does have a few sexually suggestive jokes that I found inappropriate.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewerName: Mary Jo Sminkey "15 years of Amazon Reviews!"
reviewText: This is my first experience with the "Thou Shalt Laugh" series and I was looking forward to some good comedy that I knew would be clean. I've never cared for "blue" comedy and appreciate comedians that can get a laugh without having to try and shock the audience at the same time (although these days shock value seems harder and harder to come by). Overall, this DVD succeeds on that level, but I found the quality of the comedians to be of a mixed bag. I'd say of the 6, there were two I found pretty good, a couple just good, and the others not ones I'd watch again. Dana Daniels (comedy magic) was probably my favorite, but I've had a lot of experience with magic and comedy magic in particular and while he had some unique bits, a lot of it was still pretty old hat to me. John Tesh as a host was barely passable. He's a nice enough guy and certainly well known, but boy, when he tries to do comedy bits, it *really* falls flat and was by far the worst part of watching this. I also have to consider if this is a DVD I'd pay money for...would I watch it again? I don't think I would, it's really a one-time kind of watch for me, and thus a better rental prospect than something I'd consider buying to be able to watch more than once. It just doesn't rate as high as some other comedians for me, I think back to some of the great comedians of the past that I enjoy watching on DVD, even those before my time like Red Skelton and Victor Borge. Or more recently, folks like Johnny Carson and Bill Cosby. None of the comedians on this DVD really were good enough that I'd really feel I would want to be able to watch this again. So, thumbs up for a one-time viewing, not so much for repeat viewings.
summary: Good clean laughs, but a mixed bag
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: YOU will just love it.  So funny and you can watch this comedy with your whole family young and old.  I highly recommend the series!
summary: Clean Comedy and lots of laughs
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I was a little leery about chosing this DVD thinking it would be a little too mild to be funny. But I actually found myself laughing at most of the comedians (most of whom I had never seen before). I would recommend this to anyone who is tired of dirty talking, nasty comedians and is looking for an alternative entertainment format. I loved this, will definitely be looking into prior releases to purchase for my collection.
summary: Really much funnier and entertaining than I expected
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I have to admit, I hesitated with this one, not sure what I would think of it.  Since I've been so dissatisfied with comedians in general these days, watching offensive shows and feeling like there was something wrong with me because I had difficulty actually laughing and responding like everyone else was, I thought I'd give it a try, and I was not disappointed.  If you are looking for good, clean fun, this is it.  Not sure why in our society everything geared for "adults" must be offensive and off-color, but it seems that is the way of it.  This is the exact opposite of that and you can sit back and laugh and enjoy the show!
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: All they got out of me was a few smiles, no laughs. I thought the first and second comics were pretty entertaining, but the other four had many cringe-worthy moments. I can't believe the people in the audience were laughing at these lame jokes. Maybe they have never been exposed to good comedy or the DVD was edited to make it seem they were laughing at almost everything that was said. Clean comedy is almost unheard of nowadays and it was refreshing, but the majority of this group just wasn't funny. I know many people in everyday life way funnier than these guys.
summary: It's pretty bad when a Christian based comedy series breaks one of the Ten Commandments in the title
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I wasn't really sure what to expect from Thou Shalt Not Laugh 4. I didn't really think christian comedy would be something I was interested in but I was really pleased with this set. You get a wide range of comedians who really know how to entertain people without the use of course subjects or profanity.I don't let my kids watch George Carlin but I wouldn't really consider myself a stickler when it comes to monitoring what my kids watch on TV. I found that this DVD was suitable for my children to watch and that it was something that I could enjoy with them without getting bored.Thou Shalt Not Laugh did not seem like a concept I thought I would like but I'm glad I gave it a shot. John Tesh and the rest of the comedians put on a great show and it's nice to see that their are some comedians out there who can perform sober and with clean content. Definitely worth a shot if you are a comedy fan.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I love comedy and I like a wide variety of stand-up comics. This set is better than most Christian comedy sets I've seen, but I prefer a little more cutting edge comedy. It's certainly something the family can enjoy, but for those of us who like the darker side of comedy, you can skip this one.
summary: NOT MY CUP OF TEA, BUT IT HAS ITS MOMENTS!
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: When I decided to try out Thou Shalt Laugh 4, it was more-or-less as an experiment.  I am not a religious person; in fact, I have a good deal of skepticism about religion in general.  The question was, could I still this Christian comedy show to be funny, and if I didn't, would it be because of my secular viewpoint or the fact that the comics were just not any good?I had reason to be wary:  I've found that often times, attaching "Christian" on something is just a way of sprucing up mediocrity with a cheap marketing label.  The assumption is that it doesn't have to be good; people will buy it because it's Christian (this is also done in Science Fiction, where fans will often buy anything with the Sci-Fi label).The good news is that this is actually a funny DVD that could appeal to non-Christians.  (I also watched this with a much more religious person who found it funny too.) In fact, for many of the comics, religion doesn't even get mentioned; it is more the PG-rated humor that seems to merit the Christian label.  A couple comics do get a bit preachy (and simulataneously get less funny).  And John Tesh, the emcee for the show, is better at hosting entertainment news shows and playing New Age music than he is at telling a joke.These are not the best stand-up comedians out there, but they are, for the most part funny.  The thing about humor is that when it bombs, you know it.  These folks do not bomb.  If you like your humor raunchy, this is not the DVD for you, but if you enjoy the tamer stuff too, you may like this one.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Thou Shalt laugh proves that comedy doesn't have to be vulgar as a group of "christian" comedians take the stage from within a church to tickle your funny bone.I put "Christian" in quotes because the comedy is not necessarily biblical.  The early acts only tangentially referenced Christianity, while others used it as their comic foil (Michael Jr. basing his entire act on it).John Tesh proved a pretty boring host but he spent so little time on the stage it didn't really matter. The best act was Rex Havens and the use of him as the lead was likely the wrong move, but the following acts were excellent, particularly Dana Daniels.  The only exception being Issac Witty who proved to be anything but.All in all the humor is pretty good, very clean and in some cases rather clever.I think the price is higher than it should be, but as it might be considered a niche market it's not a big surprise, with that caveat it is an excellent choice if you want to laugh at "good" humor.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: This is the christian media world trying to be hip, part 6000. John Tesch hosts a string of decent comedians as they try to marry stand up comedy with the Word. I'd say it works most of the time, and gets about as far as Donny and Marie in the wink-wink department. If you want harmless christian humor that doesn't preach, and actually DOES manage to make you smile a bit, this is it. I guess.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: With the talents of so many Christian comedians with a sprinkle of Mr. Tesh's humor and wit, this DVD is a must have for everyone who is looking for some good clean fun! Amazingly edited with the right mix of laughter and wisdom.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Clean, funny, and an all around good time Thou Shalt Laugh 4 is a great comedy show suitable for everyone.  Hosted by John Tesh and featuring a variety of very talented comedians, this dvd will keep you laughing the entire time.This is a Christian comedy show, however it isn't completely focused on religion, and the comedians although stripped of the usual foul language you see in most comedy shows still push it to the edge. All around it's fun, inventive and great if you want to have a good laugh without having to worry about whether every other word has been bleeped out. If you like this one I'd also recommend watching the other three as well.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Since this DVD was considered Christian comedy and family friendly, I asked a neighbor and her mother if they would watch this with me (I always find comedy funnier with company).  My neighbors are church goers and sensitive to profanity or any racy content, especially the 90-yo mother.Just about the only good thing I can say about this DVD is that it IS, in fact, profanity-free and pretty safe for the family.  The problem is, the family may not want to watch more than 10 minutes of it because it is just NOT funny.  John Tesh is charming as the host, but he should not have tried to be funny.  Painful!I used to go to The Improv on a regular basis, so I have seen a lot of comedians in my time.  The comedians on this DVD, though all male, were quite a diverse bunch otherwise (an African American, a Chinese American, a puppeteer, a (fake) magician, etc..).  The one thing they all had in common is that they weren't funny.  Sure, some were funnier than others.  Some were more experienced than others.Seeing that 50 of the reviewers of this DVD gave it 4- and 5-star reviews and raved about what drop-to-your-knees, gut-busting hilarity ensues, I thought it would be an enjoyable way to spend time with my neighbors.  Instead, it was awkward.  The elderly mother complained about every comic (until I finally turned it off) and the daughter tried her best to laugh to be polite...but finally, we all agreed that the funny wasn't happening and turned off the DVD.  We watched the entire performance of the first 3 comedians and then parts of one or two more.  After they left, I watched parts of the rest so that I could say I'd at least given each comic a try.I do not recommend this DVD unless you have low expectations.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I have not followed the six comedians here as the majority of my inventory is of a different rating, but it will be a decent addition for customers that ask for the clean humor.Two of the guys get a little preachy, but most of them hit the same material as other modern comics minus the language and vulgarity. Always nice to see John Tesh as I listen to his radio show some nights. The disc has no supplemental material and the pic/sound quality is average. Some of the reviewers here dissected each comedian with multiple paragraphs, but I feel most of the entertainment here did not warrant that much description.I laughed a few times at various artists, but the production value could have been a great deal better and added supplements about the artists would have been nice.
summary: A few laughs, no supplements, average quality
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I was amazed at the variety in quality on this DVD.  It ranged from the very funny Michael Jr. and Taylor Mason, both veterans of the "Thou Shalt Laugh" series to the painful to watch skits from Dana Daniels and Isaac Witty during the 1 hour and 37 minutes of the show.John Tesh did a passable just as an MC but only passable.  It felt like he really lost his skills as an entertainment reporter since he spent more time on his own weak jokes and less on making us want to watch the six comedians.First up was Rex Havens who did a decent job after a random start.  What seemed to be poor timing become a clear vehicle by which he riffed on vehicles and then slid into gender humor.Second was Joe Wong who was also a decent comedian focusing on his position as a new American to comment on his observations of his adopted country and it's impact on him.Dana Daniels' attempts at "magic" were painful to watch and I felt embarrassed for the man and woman he convinced to come up on stage.  His props only added to the campyness of the skit.Michael Jr. saved the show almost single-handedly with his observations about Christianity, the Bible, and his job as a comedian.  He could easily hold his own in any comedy venue.  Some of his jokes were very amusing even when thinking back on them later.Isaac Witty had this uncontrolled awkward laughter that ruined my enjoyment of what his random topics. Self-depreciation can be funny but this was just difficult to watch without feeling sorry for him.Taylor Mason scared me with his dummies but his skill and manipulations of them was better than most I've seen though he did skate close to the edge on a few jokes.  His musical skit was also amusing and had me laughing out loud.Overall this is a very mixed bag.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: I watched this with my husband, and to tell you the truth, I didn't care for it. My husband kept saying how cheesy this DVD was, so that also added to the frustration while watching this. I only laughed twice while watching this one. This comic's name was Joe Wong, and I laughed when I heard Rex Havens' joke about the KKK. Other than that, I felt this whole DVD was a waste of time to watch. If you're a little on the sheltered side, than this DVD is for you, but if you've "heard it all" this isn't for you. The only thing I loved completely about this DVD is the fact that children can watch this along with adults, and there's no worry about cursing, or sexual content.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: The idea of this series isn't bad -- putting together a group of comedians who elicit laughs without resorting to extreme language.  The use of profanity works for some comedians/comediennes, such as Eddie Murphy in his early years, Susie Essman (of "Curb Your Enthusiasm"), or Kathy Griffin.  But the tendency has been for younger comedians to rely on profanity at the expense of laughs, figuring that a well-placed four-letter word enunciated with exaggerated emphasis as the punchline of a lame set-up would bring down the house.  This became tired very quickly.  The comedians on this DVD reminded me of the ones who used to show up regularly on "The Ed Sullivan Show."  Don't get me wrong.  Their routines are timely, but they derive from a tradition of family entertainment rather than smoky comedy clubs or Vegas stages.  I liked the variety here.  Rather than have six guys doing straight stand-up, there's use of puppets, a magician, and some nifty swinging piano accompanying the acts.  Isaac Witty reminded me of the great Jack Benny, as he pauses after a story, waiting for the laughs to increase (which they do!).  Rex Havens tackles a topic practically every comedian in history has explored -- marriage -- yet makes some genuinely funny and original observations about that noble institution.  Dana Daniels is terrific with his on-stage partner, Luigi the parrot.  It might have been interesting to have at least one female comedienne perform in order to get a woman's point-of-view on human foibles.  The true test of this DVD is:  Did it make me laugh?  The answer:  Yes, and often.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: It was slow going at first but got better as the standup progressedIt's good clean comedy hosted by John TeshWould recommend
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Thou Shalt Laugh 4 is the fourth installment of the DVD series.  I have not watched the first three, and therefore cannot compare them.  The program consists of 6 comedians - some funny, and others not so funny.  John Tesh hosts the show.  Whether one finds these comedians funny or not depends on what that person actually expects.  So, there will be many different opinions.  Over all, I enjoyed most of the comedy acts, especially because they were good, clean humor, and something the whole family can watch.  The quality of the DVD was very good, but there were no extras, so all you get are the comedy routines.  There are other funnier comedians out there, but this DVD is good to watch when you want some clean, wholesome fun.
summary: Clean humor and a little bit funny
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4

reviewText: Several years ago I watchedThou Shalt Laughand thought it was pretty funny, and though I haven't tried out 2 or 3, I enjoyed the first enough that I was actually pretty excited about this one.  Unfortunately, the performances did not live up to my expectation.I love me some family humor and I love a good Christian-themed joke, but some of these were delivered so bad and so unprofessionally that I wanted to sound the gong or give 'em the buzz or whatever it took to get them off the stage.  Not to say they were all that way, but for the most part yes.Rex Havens gave a few good word-play jokes and poked fun at the names of cars and shoes, which were smile-worthy.  Some of skit was over-used refurbished man-and-wife jokes that had not only been done a million times but even done (better) in the other Thou Shalt Laugh.Joe Wong gave a few good quips about his experience as an Asian immigrant, but he must still be working on his English or doesn't understand comedic timing.  After every joke there was 30 seconds of awkward silence.Dana Daniels had to be the worst.  He did magic tricks that were supposed to be funny in that they weren't magic at all.  EX) taking a peek at the card before guessing which it was.Michael Jr. was the funniest, he understood timing and actually made some Christian-themed jokes which I was looking forward to (it is called Thou Shalt Laugh, right?).  His "Creepy Christians" and "Oversaved" skits were laugh-out-loud.Taylor Mason tried to impress us with poorly done ventriloquism, and Isaac Witty thought using an annoying voice would make his mild jokes funnier.All in all a truly painful experience.  If you have never seen a Thou Shalt Laugh, I can actually recommend the original, but if you're looking for comedy in that same vein, unfortunately this just isn't it.
Title: Thou Shalt Laugh 4
